Award.AwardTitle: Selective Sustained Attention and Learning in Young Children

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Selective sustained attention is the ability to maintain focus on some aspects of the environment over time while ignoring others. The ability to engage in selective sustained attention is crucial for learning and processing important information. This ability is influenced both by exogenous factors (relating to the characteristics of the environment, such as how noticeable, interesting, or novel an object is) and endogenous factors (relating to the characteristics of the individual, such as motivation or remembering the task goals). Over development, children become less easily influenced by exogenous factors, and endogenous factors begin to play a more important role. This project investigates how developmental change in the relative contributions of endogenous and exogenous factors influences different kinds of learning.

Selective sustained attention develops throughout childhood, such that endogenous factors become more powerful in guiding attention. There are numerous experimental paradigms for studying sustained attention in infancy and adulthood. However, few experimental paradigms are appropriate for use with children between the ages of approximately 2 and 7 years, the period of heightened development of endogenous regulation of selective sustained attention. The investigators have developed a task --the Track-It task-- appropriate for studying selective sustained attention in children in this age range. In the Track-It task, children visually track a moving object on a screen, surrounded by either homogenous or heterogeneous moving distracters, and report the location of the target's disappearance. Performance on this task can distinguish between the contribution of endogenous and exogenous factors to sustained attention. This project will use response accuracy and patterns of eye movements in the Track-It task to: (1) investigate the development of endogenous regulation of selective sustained attention, and (2) investigate how exogenous and endogenous attention regulation contributes to implicit versus explicit learning. This research will advance understanding of the development of attention regulation and its implications for different types of learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Selective sustained attention refers to one's ability to maintain focus on a single object or task for a period of time. This ability is fundamental to learning and performance in contexts ranging from infants learning their first words to college students learning calculus. Yet, researchers often find it challenging to characterize developmental trajectories and individual differences in selective sustained attention during the preschool years due to a paucity of assessment tools appropriate for young children. To address this challenge, this project refined a developmentally-appropriate and developmentally-sensitive tool to assess selective sustained attention in young children. This assessment is administered on a computer and presented to children as a simple "computer game" called TrackIt. In this game, children are asked to visually track an object moving on a computer screen and report the final location where this object "disappears" from the screen. Task difficulty can be changed by adding other objects that may distract a child from the target object and/or increasing the length of time when the objects are moving on the screen. We found that the TrackIt assessment is most appropriate for children 3 to 6 years of age - the age range which had been particularly challenging to assess using existing tools. The utility of TrackIt is attested by the fact that other researchers have already begun using it in their own research (we made the TrackIt task freely available to all researchers interested in using it: https://sites.google.com/andrew.cmu.edu/trackit/home). Researchers on this project found that individual differences in performance on the TrackIt task are predictive of children's success in learning age-appropriate science content in a classroom-like setting.

To further increase the utility of the TrackIt tool in child development research, the project team developed a new technique for automated analysis of eye movements elicited in this task, called "smooth pursuit" eye movements. Smooth pursuit eye movements allow humans to visually track a moving object and are very common in our daily experiences. Yet, this type of movement is notoriously difficult to analyze without using human coders, which is time consuming and open to reliability failures. This project supported the development of a first of its kind automated analysis of smooth pursuit eye movements, an innovation that is useful to researchers studying child development as well as researchers in other disciplines. 

Overall, this project led to the publication of 5 peer-reviewed conference proceedings papers, 4 peer-reviewed journal articles, and 1 book chapter; numerous presentations at national and international conferences; and the creation of a website to make the TrackIt tool freely available to other researchers. This project provided training and professional development opportunities to 1 post-doctoral researcher, 4 graduate students, 5 research staff members, and 24 undergraduate students (including 10 members of groups underrepresented in graduate degree training programs). Finally, this project provided numerous opportunities for public outreach: project co-PIs and team members held multiple meetings with educators, school administrators, parents, and members of the public to discuss research on the development of sustained attention, thereby increasing scientific literacy and engagement with science in the community.
